doc.field: An hymn to may ; [by Thomas Cooke
An hymn to may ; [by Thomas Cooke
An hymn to may ; [by Thomas Cooke
<name>Printed for R. and J. Dodsley ... and sold by M. Cooper [etc.]</name>
Solvitur acris Hyems grata Vice Veris et Favoni: Jam Cytherea Choros ducit, imminente Luna; Junctæque Nymphis Gratiæ decentes Alterno Terram quatiunt Pede. Hor. Lib. 1. Od. 4.

AN HYMN TO MAY. To the Right Honourable SUSAN Countess of Shaftesbury. Fairest Daughter of the Day, Lovely Goddess, spritely May, Hither come with Roses crown'd, Painting where you tread the Ground: You the Vales and Hills adorn; You rejoice the dappled Morn: At the lov'd Approach of thee Shoots the Mulb'ry, tim'rous Tree, Vines their tender Leaves unfold; Nor the Fig-tree dreads the Cold: Now the flow'ry Lote is seen; Last the stately Oak is green. Nymph divine, behold the Flow'rs Rise to grace thy vernal Hours: Woodbines, spangled o'er with Dew, Deck their Arborets for you: Th'A'mony of various Dy, Who when either Wind is high Hides her ever bashful Face, Opens to thy soft Embrace. See the purple Iris blow, Tinged by the wat'ry Bow, Chose by Lewis in the Field To adorn the Gallic Shield: Tulips rear their glitt'ring Heads, Pinks bestrew their fragrant Beds, Near the blushing maiden Rose Now the fair Narcissus blows, And for thee the Lillys swell, And the golden Asphodel. Fav'rite of the tuneful Quire, Goddess who can wake the Lyre, Hear the Birds around thee sing: In each Garden of the Spring Ev'ry Bush, and ev'ry Tree, Warble forth their Joy to thee: Couch'd amidst the flow'ry Thorn Philomela wakes the Morn; When whose plaintive Note is done, Th'early Lark salutes the Sun: Nature's Songsters all are gay At the lov'd Approach of May. Goddess with thy Vest of Green, Goddess with thy youthful Mien, Come, and bring thy Mines of Wealth, Gladness, and her Parent Health: Chac'd by thee from Albion's Shore, Surly Winter howls no more, Shiv'ring in his Coat of Snow, With his icy Chin and Brow: Now no more his frozen Train Blast the Hopes of Flora's Reign. Goddess softer than the Dove, Lovely as the Queen of Love, Round whose Bosom Zephyrs play With the Sun's prolific Ray, Drive away the sickly Gloom, Blaster that of ev'ry Bloom, Of the Garden Flow'r, and Rose On the Virgin-cheek that blows: Chase away grim Care and Pain; Bring along thy joyful Train; Wit and Humour bring along, With the chaste and lively Song: Now the Loves and Graces all Throng obedient to thy Call; With the Wood-Nymphs they advance, Joining in the mazy Dance. Goddess haste, and bring with thee Virtue's Child fair Liberty; For, if Liberty's away, Who can taste the Sweets of May? See Provencial Olives blow, And the Vats of Bourdeaux flow; Pallas yet would have her Tree Flourish where her Sons are free. Bacchus, ever youthful God, With his Wreath and verdant Rod, Gives the Vines of France Encrease, As he gives the Vines of Greece, Yet the lib'ral God disdains French alike and Greecian Plains, And the mirthful Spirit sends To his freeborn British Friends; And with them he keeps his Court; And with them he deigns to sport: Here he comes, I hear the Sound Of his merry Songsters round: Know him by his Forehead sleek, And the Roses on his Cheek, By his sparkling Eyes, and Smile Which is ever free from Guile, By his Thyrsus, and his Wreath, By his leafy Belt beneath: Here he comes, and, never fear, Brings no wanton Revels here; Here he comes, all fresh and gay, Doing Homage to the May. Goddess who perfum'st the Air, Who hast deck'd the Earth so fair, Thou, with Gladness by thy Side, Lay'st the Raging of the Tyde, Bid'st the Winds forbear to roar; And the Tempest's hear'd no more: Meads, and Groves, and Valleys, sing: Love himself now plumes his Wing. Now the love-inspired Swain Breathes his Vows, and sighs his Pain, Hastens to th'appointed Shade, Casts his Eyes along the Glade, Ev'ry Moment thinks an Hour, Till he reach the blissful Bow'r. Flora now her Zephyr leads Thro the Gardens, Groves, and Meads; On each sunny Bank they play, Heedless of the Eye of Day, Seeking, Morn and Noon, Delight, And beneath the Dews of Night, Till the Goddess pregnant grows, Fearless of a Mother's Throws: Juno then and fost'ring Earth Kindly aid the fruitful Birth, And the beauteous Offsprings lay In the fragrant Lap of May. Thou Apollo's sweetest Child, Thou who deck'st the Desart wild, All the Odours of the Spring, All thine healthful Treasures, bring, Long thy gentle Warmth diffuse Round the tenth, the British, Muse; Frequently O! may'st thou deign, With thy cheerful annual Train, To salute the lovely'st Dame That adorns the Book of Fame: Round her pour thy balmy Breez, Sooth her Soul with Health and Ease; Tho from Heav'n deriv'd her Birth, Tempt her long to stay on Earth; Tempt thy Shaftesb'ry, lovely May, From her native Skys to stay, Long to breathe thy vernal Air, Fairest Pattern to the Fair! Then I'll wake to thee the Lyre, Rouse the emulating Quire, Who shall all thy Praises sing, Hail thee Emp'ress of the Spring, Blooming Nymph of heav'nly Birth, Goddess thou of Health and Mirth. The END.
